Literature Review: SWI/SNF chromatin remodelers play a crucial role in regulating gene expression, cell fate reprogramming, and responses to environmental challenges. These complexes utilize the energy derived from ATP hydrolysis to facilitate access of proteins to the genomic DNA, enabling transcription, replication, and DNA repair. The unique ability of SWI/SNF remodelers to slide or eject the histone octamer along the DNA or from the DNA, respectively, allows for the dynamic reorganization of chromatin structure. This dynamic reorganization is essential for the proper functioning of transcription factors and the regulation of enhancer activity. Recent advances in cryo-electron microscopy and mass spectrometry have revealed the existence of different subtypes of SWI/SNF complexes with distinct properties and functions. These subtypes have been shown to have unique roles in regulating chromatin structure and function in animals and plants. For example, the SWI/SNF complex in Drosophila melanogaster has been shown to play a critical role in regulating the expression of developmental genes (1). In contrast, the SWI/SNF complex in Arabidopsis thaliana has been shown to play a role in regulating the expression of stress-responsive genes (2). The subunit composition of SWI/SNF complexes has also been shown to play a critical role in regulating their activity. For example, the presence of the ATPase subunit has been shown to be essential for the activity of SWI/SNF complexes (3). Furthermore, posttranslational modifications of SWI/SNF subunits have been shown to play a critical role in regulating their activity. For example, the phosphorylation of the ATPase subunit has been shown to enhance its activity (4). The chromatin context has also been shown to play a critical role in regulating SWI/SNF activity. For example, the presence of specific histone modifications has been shown to enhance or inhibit SWI/SNF activity (5). In addition, the interaction between SWI/SNF complexes and Polycomb complexes has been shown to play a critical role in regulating chromatin structure and function. For example, the interaction between SWI/SNF complexes and Polycomb complexes has been shown to regulate the expression of developmental genes (6). Overall, the unique ability of SWI/SNF remodelers to dynamically reorganize chromatin structure and function makes them critical regulators of gene expression and cell fate reprogramming. Their activity is tightly controlled by complex subunit composition, posttranslational modifications, and the chromatin context, highlighting the importance of understanding the mechanisms underlying their regulation.
